{{Redirect|Askeran}} {{Use dmy dates|date=July 2013}} {{Infobox settlement |name = Askeran |official_name = Ասկերան
Əsgəran |native_name = |image_skyline = District court in Askeran.jpg |image_caption = District court in Askeran |pushpin_map = Republic of Artsakh |pushpin_mapsize = 300 |subdivision_type = ''[[de jure]]'' Country |subdivision_name = {{flag|Azerbaijan}} |subdivision_type1 = ''de jure'' [[Administrative divisions of Azerbaijan|Rayon]] |subdivision_name1 = [[Khojaly District|Khojaly]] |subdivision_type2 = ''[[de facto]]'' Country |subdivision_name2 = {{flag|Artsakh}} |subdivision_type3 = ''de facto'' [[Administrative divisions of the Republic of Artsakh|Province]] |subdivision_name3 = [[Askeran Province|Askeran]] |leader_title = Mayor |leader_name = |established_title = |established_date = |area_total_km2 = |area_footnotes = |population_as_of = 2015 |population_total = 2,300 |population_footnotes = http://stat-nkr.am/files/publications/2015/LXH_tverov_2015.pdf |population_density_km2 = auto |timezone = [[UTC]] |utc_offset = +4 |timezone_DST = |utc_offset_DST = |coordinates = {{coord|39|56|12|N|46|49|58|E|region:{{xb|NKR}}|display=inline,title}} |elevation_m = |area_code = |website = }} '''Askeran''' ({{lang-hy|Ասկերան}}, {{lang-az|Əsgəran}}; also, '''Khachen''') is a town in the [[Republic of Artsakh]] and the administrative center of the [[Askeran Province]] which is coextensive with [[Khojali Rayon]] of [[Azerbaijan]]. == History == [[Askeran fortress]] is situated in the southern suburb of the town. The fortress was built for defense of [[Shusha]]. The fortress was widely used during the [[Russo-Persian War (1804–1813)|Russo-Persian War]]. In the 1988 in the [[Askeran clash|clash]] in this city was one of the igniting points of [[Armenian people|Armenian]]-[[Azerbaijani people|Azerbaijani]] conflict resulting in [[Nagorno-Karabakh War]]. The fortress of Askeran was renovated in 2002. ==Gallery== File:Askeran fortress2.jpg|[[Askeran fortress]] File:Ասկերանի մայրաբերդ2.JPG|General view of [[Askeran fortress]] File:Askeran037.JPG|Church of the Holy Mother of God in Askeran, opened in 2002 File:Askeran Marzadasht 26.06.2011.jpg|Askeran City Stadium == References == {{Reflist}} {{Commons category|Askeran}} *{{GEOnet2|32FA88151EB13774E0440003BA962ED3}} *[https://web.archive.org/web/20110622020159/http://world-gazetteer.com/wg.php?x=&men=gcis&lng=en&des=wg&geo=-26&srt=npan&col=abcdefghinoq&msz=1500&pt=c&va=x World Gazetteer: Azerbaijan] – World-Gazetteer.com *[http://census.stat-nkr.am/nkr/1-1.pdf Population of Nagorno-Karabakh Republic (2005)] {{Administrative divisions of Artsakh}} {{Askeran Province}} {{Khojali Rayon}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Askeran (Town)}} [[Category:Populated places in Askeran province]] [[Category:Populated places in Khojali District]] {{NagornoKarabakh-geo-stub}} {{Khojali-geo-stub}}

{{Use dmy dates|date=July 2015}} {{Infobox organization |native_name = Fonds zur Förderung der wissenschaftlichen Forschung |native_name_lang=de |image = |image_border = |size = <!-- default 200 --> |alt = <!-- alt text; see [[WP:ALT]] --> |caption = FWF Logo |map = <!-- optional --> |msize = <!-- map size, optional, default 200px --> |malt = <!-- map alt text --> |mcaption = <!-- optional --> |abbreviation = FWF |motto = We strengthen science and the humanities in Austria |formation = {{Start date and years ago|df=yes|1968|03|04}} |extinction = <!-- date of extinction, optional --> |type = <!-- [[Governmental organization|GO]], [[Non-governmental organization|NGO]], [[Intergovernmental organization|IGO]], [[International nongovernmental organization|INGO]], etc --> |status = <!-- ad hoc, treaty, foundation, etc --> |purpose = <!-- focus as e.g. humanitarian, peacekeeping, etc --> |headquarters = |location = [[Vienna]] |coords = |region_served = |membership = |language = <!-- official languages --> |leader_title = <!-- position title for the leader of the org --> |leader_name = <!-- name of leader --> |main_organ = <!-- gral. assembly, board of directors, etc --> |parent_organization = <!-- if one --> |affiliations = <!-- if any --> |num_staff = |num_volunteers = |budget = |website = [http://www.fwf.ac.at/ fwf.ac.at] |remarks = }} The '''Austrian Science Fund''' ({{lang-de|Fonds zur Förderung der wissenschaftlichen Forschung, FWF}}) is the most important [[Austria]]n funding organization for basic research. The FWF supports research in [[science]], [[engineering]], and the [[humanities]] through a large variety of grant programmes, [[prize]]s and by funding infrastructure. The self-governed organization is based in [[Vienna]] and financed by the Austrian federal government.
==Organisation==
The Austrian Science Fund was established in 1967 and had a budget of 91 million euros in 2001. Most projects are individual research grants for up to three years. In addition, it also supports national research clusters, doctoral schools, scholarships for young researchers and awards like the ''[[Start-Preis|START]]-'' and [[Wittgenstein-Preis]]. [[Pascale Ehrenfreund]] was elected president of the FWF on 6 June 2013. In recent years, the Austrian Science Fund provides growing support for the publication of articles and monographs in the [[open access]] format.<ref>{{cite web |url= http://openscience.com/the-austrian-science-fund-endorses-de-gruyter-open-for-its-open-access-publishing-program/ |title=The Austrian Science Fund Endorses De Gruyter for its Open Access Publishing Program |first=Pablo |last=Markin |work=[[OpenScience]] |date=14 April 2017 |accessdate=17 April 2017}}</ref>
== Membership ==
The Austrian Science Fund is a member of the [[European Science Foundation]].
==See also== * [[Open access in Austria]]
==References== <references />
==External links== * [http://www.fwf.ac.at/en/ official website] {{en icon}} * [http://in-cites.com/research/2007/november_26_2007-2.html Science in Austria, 2002-06]

{{Infobox musical artist | name = Camerton / Камертон / {{MongolUnicode|ᠺᠠᠮᠡᠷᠲᠤᠨ}} | image = | landscape = yes | caption = Camerton in November 2015
L to R: Gana, Bold, Eba and Mede | image_size = | background = group_or_band | alias = | origin = [[Ulaanbaatar]], [[Mongolia]] | instrument = | genre = [[Pop music|Pop]], [[Soul music|soul]], [[adult contemporary]], [[Rhythm and blues|R&B]], [[Hip Hop|hip hop]] | occupation = | years_active = 1995 – 2004 | label = | associated_acts = | website = | current_members = Bold, Erdenebat, Mend-Amar, Gan-Erdene | past_members = }} '''Camerton''' ({{lang-mn|Камертон}}, after the Russian word for [[tuning fork]]) are a [[Mongolia]]n [[vocal group]]. They independently formed on June 24, 1995. The same year they won "Best Debut Group" at the [[Pentatonic Award]], the biggest music awards in Mongolia. Widely considered as the first and the most successful pop/boy band in Mongolia, Camerton have released a total of ten albums and EPs between 1996 and 2004. At the peak of their success, the band's popularity spanned throughout [[East Asia]], most notably in Taiwan, where they have exclusively released a "best of" compilation. Their song "Don't I think About You" has been included in an Asian All Stars' CD, named "Love is The Answer". Following the release of "Celebration" EP in 2004, Camerton announced their hiatus. All four members of the group immediately went on to launch solo careers, most prominently Bold, who released several solo albums since 2005 and started a musical project named "Mongol Pop". The band occasionally reunites for one-time concerts and performances, most notable ones include their tenth and twentieth anniversary concerts in 2005 and 2015 respectively. In January 2015, they released a brand new song called "{{Lang|mn|Асах Гэрэл}}" (''Asakh Gerel''), a [[soundtrack]] for the film "{{Lang|mn|Давхар Цохилт}}" (''Davkhar Tsohilt''), with a new music video. In November 2015, the band played another sold-out concert in Ulaanbaatar. The concert named '18 Years' (the original title of their debut concert in 1996) consisted of 40 songs. Following their hugely successful concert, Bold announced via his [[Facebook]] page that Camerton would be releasing a new album in 2016, the band's first release in more than a decade. == Discography == * {{Lang|mn|18 нас}} (''18 Years'', 1996) * {{Lang|mn|Уйлахдаа ухаар}} (''Uilakhdaa Ukhaar'', 1998) * {{Lang|mn|Амин нутаг}} EP (''Beloved Motherland'', 1999) * {{Lang|mn|June 24}} (2000) * {{Lang|mn|Retro II Remix}} (2000) * {{Lang|mn|Төгсөшгүй}} (''Endless'', 2001) * {{Lang|mn|Өнөөдөр}} (''Today'', 2003) * {{Lang|mn|Хайрын хот}} EP (''City of Love'', 2003) * {{Lang|mn|June 2004}} (2004) * {{Lang|mn|Celebration}} EP (2004) * {{Lang|mn|Хязгааргүй}} EP (2017) == References == * {{Cite web | title = Camerton Recording New Album | url = http://ubpost.mongolnews.mn/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=1471&Itemid=45 | publisher = [[UB Post]] | author = Ts.Lkhagvasuren | date = 2008-03-06 | accessdate = 2008-11-02 }} * {{Cite web |title = Камертон |url = http://www.duu.mn/singer.php?sinid=1 |publisher = www.duu.mn, Mongolian music portal |language = Mongolian |author = |date = |accessdate = 2008-11-02 |archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20081204233501/http://www.duu.mn/singer.php?sinid=1# |archive-date = 2008-12-04 |dead-url = yes |df = }} {{Music of Mongolia}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Camerton}} [[Category:Mongolian musical groups]] [[Category:Boy bands]] {{Asia-band-stub}}

revision.text:
{{Infobox event | title = Constantinople Conference | image =Constantinople Conference.jpg | image_size = | image_alt = | caption = Conference delegates | native_name = Tersane Konferansı | native_name_lang = tr | english_name = | time = | duration = | date = {{start and end dates|1876|12|23|1877|01|20}} | venue = Constantinople | location = | coordinates = <!-- {{coord|LAT|LON|region:XXXX_type:event|display=inline,title}} --> | also_known_as = | type = Conference | theme = Bosnia and the Ottoman territories with a majority Bulgarian population | cause = The Herzegovinian Uprising in 1875 and the Bulgarian April Uprising in 1876 | first_reporter = | budget = | patron = <!-- or |patrons= --> | organisers = <!-- or |organizers= --> | filmed_by = | participants = Britain, Russia, France, Germany, Austria-Hungary and Italy | outcome = Agreed on a project for political reforms | casualties1 = | casualties2 = | casualties3 = | reported deaths = | reported injuries = | reported missing = | reported property damage = | burial = | inquiries = | inquest = | coroner = | arrests = | suspects = | accused = | convicted = | charges = | trial = | verdict = | convictions = | sentence = | publication_bans = | litigation = | awards = | url = | blank_label = <!-- or |blank_data= --> | blank1_label = <!-- or |blank1_data= --> | blank2_label = <!-- or |blank2_data= --> | website = <!-- {{URL|example.com}} --> | notes = }}
{{Use dmy dates|date=September 2011}}
The 1876–77 '''Constantinople Conference''' ({{lang-tr|Tersane Konferansı}} "Shipyard Conference", after the venue ''Tersane Sarayı'' "Shipyard Palace") of the [[Great power|Great Powers]] ([[United Kingdom of Great Britain and Ireland|Britain]], [[Russian Empire|Russia]], [[French Third Republic|France]], [[German Empire|Germany]], [[Austria-Hungary]] and [[Kingdom of Italy (1861–1946)|Italy]]) was held in [[Names of Istanbul|Constantinople]] (now [[Istanbul]])<ref>Finkel, Caroline, ''Osman's Dream'', (Basic Books, 2005), 57; "''Istanbul was only adopted as the city's official name in 1930.''".</ref> from 23 December 1876 until 20 January 1877. Following the beginning of the [[Herzegovina Uprising (1875–1878)|Herzegovinian Uprising]] in 1875 and the [[April Uprising]] in April 1876, the Great Powers agreed on a project for political reforms both in [[Bosnia]] and in the [[Ottoman Empire|Ottoman]] territories with a majority<ref>Correspondence respecting the Conference at Constantinople and the affairs of Turkey: 1876–1877. Parliamentary Papers No 2 (1877). p. 340.</ref> [[Bulgarians|Bulgarian]] population.
==Participants== [[File:Balkan boundaries1876map1914.png|thumb|400px|Bulgaria according to the Constantinople Conference]] The Great Powers were represented at the conference respectively by:<ref>H. Sutherland Edwards. [https://archive.org/stream/sirwilliamwhite00edwagoog/sirwilliamwhite00edwagoog_djvu.txt ''Sir William White K.C.B., K.C.M.G., For Six Years Ambassador at Constantinople''.] London: John Murray, 1902.</ref>
* [[United Kingdom of Great Britain and Ireland]]: : [[Robert Cecil, 3rd Marquess of Salisbury|Lord Salisbury]] and Sir [[Henry Elliot]]; * [[Russian Empire]]: : Count [[Nikolay Pavlovich Ignatyev|Nikolay Ignatyev]] (historical spelling Nicolai Ignatieff); * [[French Third Republic|French Republic]]: : Count [[Jean-Baptiste Alexandre Damaze de Chaudordy|Jean-Baptiste de Chaudordy]] and Count [[François de Bourgoing]]; * [[German Empire]]: : Baron [[Karl von Werther]]; * [[Austro-Hungarian Empire]]: : Baron [[Heinrich von Calice]] and Count [[Zichy#Prominent Members of Zichy ancestry|Ferenc Zichy]]; * [[Kingdom of Italy (1861–1946)|Kingdom of Italy]]: : Count [[Lodovico, Count Corti|Luigi (Lodovico) Corti]].
Of these, [[Lord]] Salisbury, [[Count]] de Chaudordy and [[Baron]] von Calice were [[Ambassador|Ambassadors Plenipotentiary]] to the conference, while Count Ignatyev, Sir Henry Elliot, Count de Bourgoing, Baron von Werther, Count Zichy and Count Corti were the resident Ambassadors of their countries in Constantinople.
The US [[Consul (representative)|Consul General]] in Constantinople, [[Eugene Schuyler]] also took an active part in drafting the conference decisions.<ref>[https://timesmachine.nytimes.com/timesmachine/1876/12/31/93824050.pdf The Eastern Question. The Constantinople Conference. What May Be Expected from the Meeting. The Foreign Representatives and How They Are Treated. The Report of the American Consul General. Various Items of Interest.] New York Times, 31 December 1876.</ref><ref>{{citation |last=Schuyler|first= Eugene|contribution= United Bulgaria|title=The North American Review|volume=141 |issue=348 |date= November 1885 |pages=464–474 |jstor=25118547 |accessdate=}}</ref>
The [[Ottoman Empire]] was represented at the conference by: : [[Midhat Pasha]], [[Saffet Pasha]] and [[Ibrahim Edhem Pasha|Edhem Pasha]].
Midhat [[Pasha]] was the [[Grand Vizier]] (First Minister), and Saffet Pasha the Foreign Minister of the Ottoman Empire. Although the Ottoman representatives participated in the plenaries of the conference, they were not invited to the preceding working sessions at which the Great Powers negotiated and elaborated their agreement.
Lord Salisbury and Count Ignatyev played a leading role in the process. Ignatyev was trying to dispel British misgivings about Russia’s assumed role of a protector of the [[Orthodox Church|Orthodox]] [[South Slavs|Slavs]] being but a disguise of its drive to take over the [[Turkish Straits|Black Sea Straits]] and Constantinople itself and thus – as Prime Minister [[Benjamin Disraeli|Disraeli]] feared – potentially threaten the vital [[Mediterranean Sea|Mediterranean]] routes to [[British India]].<ref>Buckle G.E., W.F. Monypenny, [https://archive.org/stream/lifeofbenjamindi05monyuoft/lifeofbenjamindi05monyuoft_djvu.txt The Constantinople Conference], in: ''The Life of Benjamin Disraeli, Earl of Beaconsfield''. Vol. VI, p. 84.</ref> On his part, Salisbury saw the conference as a promising opportunity for mapping out a comprehensive deal with Russia over their conflicting territorial ambitions in Central Asia.<ref>Sneh Mahajan. [https://books.google.com/books?id=Wl7sYKcR6hwC&printsec=frontcover&dq=%22Sneh+Mahajan%22&hl=en&ei=MAiqS8KVMsSK_Ab3wYCyAQ&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=1&ved=0CDMQ6AEwAA#v=onepage&q=&f=false ''British Foreign Policy, 1874–1914: The role of India''.] London and New York: Routledge, 2002. p. 40.</ref>
==Decisions== [[File:Marqués de salisbury.jpg|thumb|110px|Lord Salisbury]] [[File:N.P.Ignatiev by Kustodiev.jpg|thumb|110px|Count Ignatieff]] [[File:Hottinger Volksblatt 1878 065 Bild1.jpg|thumb|110px|Sultan Abdul Hamid II]]
===Bosnia===
The conference envisaged the creation of an [[autonomy|autonomous]] province including [[Bosnia (region)|Bosnia]] and most of [[Herzegovina]], while a southern part of the latter was to be ceded to the [[Principality of Montenegro]].{{citation needed|date=January 2017}}
===Bulgaria===
The Great Powers agreed on a substantial Bulgarian autonomy to take the form of two new Ottoman provinces ([[Wilayah#Ottoman Empire|vilayets]]) established for the purpose: Eastern, with capital [[Veliko Tarnovo|Tarnovo]], and Western, with capital [[Sofia]].<ref name="Ivanova"/><ref name="Compte rendu No. 8"/>
The conference determined that, as of the late 19th century, the Bulgarian ethnic territories within the Ottoman Empire extended to [[Tulcea]] and the [[Danube Delta]] in the northeast, [[Ohrid]] and [[Kastoria]] in the southwest, [[Kirklareli]] and [[Edirne]] in the southeast, and [[Leskovac]] and [[Niš]] in the northwest. These territories were to be incorporated into the two Bulgarian autonomous provinces as follows:
* Eastern Bulgarian autonomous province, including the Ottoman [[sandjak]]s – second level administrative divisions – of [[Veliko Tarnovo|Tırnova]], [[Ruse, Bulgaria|Rusçuk]], [[Tulcea|Tulça]], [[Varna]], [[Sliven]], [[Plovdiv|Filibe]] (bar the [[kaza (country subdivision)|kaza]]s – third level administrative divisions – of [[Ardino|Sultaneri]] and [[Smolyan|Ahıçelebi]]), and part of the [[Edirne]] sandjak including the kazas of [[Kırklareli|Kırkkilise]], [[Svilengrad|Mustafapaşa]] and [[Elhovo|Kızılağaç]].<ref name="Compte rendu No. 8">Conference de Constantinople. Reunions Préliminaires. Compte rendu No. 8. Scéance du 21 décembre 1876. Annexe III Bulgare. Règlement organique. (in French)</ref><ref name="Maps">Further Correspondence respecting the affairs of Turkey. (With Maps of proposed Bulgarian Vilayets). Parliamentary Papers No 13 (1877).</ref> * Western Bulgarian autonomous province, including the sandjaks of [[Sofia|Sofya]], [[Vidin]], [[Niš|Niş]], [[Skopje|Üsküp]], [[Bitola|Manastır]] (bar the kazas of [[Debar|Debre]] and [[Korçë|Korça]]), the [[Gotse Delchev (town)|Nevrokop]], [[Melnik, Bulgaria|Melnik]] and [[Sidirokastro|Demirhisar]] kazas of the [[Serres|Serez]] sandjak, and the kazas of [[Strumica|Ustrumca]], [[Veles (city)|Köprülü]], [[Tikveš|Tikveş]] and [[Kastoria|Kesriye]].<ref name="Compte rendu No. 8" /><ref name="Maps" />
The Great Powers elaborated in detail the constitutional, [[Legislative Assembly|legislative]], executive, [[Defense (military)|defense]] and [[Law enforcement agency|law enforcement]] arrangements, [[Canton (administrative division)|canton]]al [[Local government|administrative]] system, taxation, international supervision etc. for the proposed autonomous provinces.<ref name="Ivanova"/><ref name="Compte rendu No. 8"/>
==Conclusion==
The agreed decisions of the six Great Powers were formally handed over to the [[Ottoman Empire|Ottoman]] Government on 23 December 1876,<ref>Correspondence respecting the Conference at Constantinople and the affairs of Turkey: 1876–1877. Parliamentary Papers No 2 (1877). p. 140.</ref> dismissing the opening Ottoman suggestions that the Conference's mission might be unnecessary, given a new [[Kanunuesasi|Ottoman Constitution]] approved by [[Sultan]] [[Abdul Hamid II]] that same day.<ref>L.S. Stavrianos. [https://web.archive.org/web/20010311191618/http://www.serbianunity.net/culture/history/berlin78/index.html#Constantinople%20Conference Constantinople Conference], in: ''The Balkans Since 1453''. Austin: Holt, Rinehart and Winston, 1963.</ref> In the subsequent conference's plenary sessions, the Ottoman Empire submitted objections and alternative reform proposals that were rejected by the Great Powers, and attempts to bridge the gap did not succeed.<ref>[https://timesmachine.nytimes.com/timesmachine/1877/01/16/80361295.pdf Turkey and the Great Powers. The Constantinople Conference. The Commissioners' Last Proposals to the Porte. An Ultimatum Presented the Great Dignitaries of State to Decide Upon an Answer.] New York Times, 16 January 1877.</ref> Eventually, on 18 January 1877 Grand Vizier [[Midhat Pasha]] announced the definitive refusal of the Ottoman Empire to accept the conference decisions.<ref name="Ivanova">N. Ivanova. [https://web.archive.org/web/20120314015523/http://members.multimania.co.uk/rre/Constantinople-Conference-BG.pdf 1876 Constantinople Conference: Positions of the Great Powers on the Bulgarian political question during the Conference.] Sofia University, 2007. (in Bulgarian)</ref>
==Legacy==
The rejection by the Ottoman Government of the decisions of the Constantinople Conference triggered the 1877–1878 [[Russo-Turkish War (1877–1878)|Russo-Turkish War]], depriving at the same time the Ottoman Empire – in contrast to the preceding 1853–1856 [[Crimean War]] – of Western support.<ref name="Ivanova" />
[[Tsarigrad Peak]] in [[Imeon Range]] on [[Smith Island (South Shetland Islands)|Smith Island]] in the [[South Shetland Islands]], [[Antarctica]] is named after the conference (‘[[Tsarigrad]]’ being the old Bulgarian name for Constantinople).<ref>[http://data.aad.gov.au/aadc/gaz/scar/display_name.cfm?gaz_id=136841 Tsarigrad Peak.] [[Scientific Committee on Antarctic Research|SCAR]] [[Composite Gazetteer of Antarctica]].</ref>
==See also== {| style="float:right" |- | [[File:constantinople conference west.jpg|thumb|180px|Western Bulgarian autonomous province]] | [[File:constantinople conference east.jpg|thumb|180px|Eastern Bulgarian autonomous province]] |} * [[Herzegovina uprising (1875–1877)]] * [[April Uprising]] * [[Russo-Turkish War (1877–1878)]]
==Maps== * [https://web.archive.org/web/20180916153416/http://www.archives.government.bg/images/karta.jpg Bulgaria in the borders after the Treaties of Constantinople, San-Stephano, Berlin, London, Bucharest and Neuilly.] Scale 1:1600000 map. (in German)
==Notes== {{reflist|30em}}
==References== * R.W. Seton-Watson. ''Disraeli, Gladstone and the Eastern Question: A Study in Diplomacy and Party Politics''. New York: W.W. Norton & Co., 1972. p. 108. {{ISBN|978-0-393-00594-3}} * {{Cite book |last= Washburn|first=George |year=1909 |title=Fifty Years in Constantinople and Recollections of Robert College |publisher=Houghton Mufflin Company |place=Boston & New York |edition= 1 |pages=115–119 |url=https://archive.org/stream/fiftyyearsincons00wash#page/n7/mode/2up|accessdate= March 9, 2017 |via= Internet Archive}}.
{{Great Eastern Crisis}}
[[Category:History of Europe]] [[Category:Politics of the Ottoman Empire]] [[Category:Great Eastern Crisis]] [[Category:1876 in the Ottoman Empire]] [[Category:1877 in the Ottoman Empire]] [[Category:Bulgarian National Revival]] [[Category:Macedonia under the Ottoman Empire]] [[Category:1876 conferences]] [[Category:1877 conferences]]

{{Economics sidebar}}The idea of '''convergence''' in economics (also sometimes known as the '''catch-up effect''') is the hypothesis that poorer [[Economic system|economies]]' [[per capita income]]s will tend to grow at faster rates than richer economies. As a result, all economies should eventually converge in terms of per capita income. [[Developing country|Developing countries]] have the potential to grow at a faster rate than [[developed country|developed countries]] because [[diminishing returns]] (in particular, to [[Capital (economics)|capital]]) are not as strong as in capital-rich countries. Furthermore, poorer countries can replicate the production methods, [[technology|technologies]], and [[institutions]] of developed countries.
In [[economic growth]] literature the term "convergence" can have two meanings. The first kind (sometimes called "sigma-convergence") refers to a reduction in the [[Statistical dispersion|dispersion]] of levels of income across economies. "Beta-convergence" on the other hand, occurs when poor economies grow faster than rich ones. Economists say that there is "conditional beta-convergence" when economies experience "beta-convergence" but conditional on other variables (namely the investment rate and the population growth rate) being held constant. They say that "unconditional beta-convergence" or "absolute beta-convergence" exists when the growth rate of an economy declines as it approaches its [[Steady-state economy|steady state]]. According to [[Jack Goldstone]], "in the twentieth century, the [[Great Divergence]] peaked before the First World War and continued until the early 1970s, then, after two decades of indeterminate fluctuations, in the late 1980s it was replaced by the Great Convergence as the majority of Third World countries reached economic growth rates significantly higher than those in most First World countries",<ref>[http://cliodynamics.ru/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=378&Itemid=1 Phases of global demographic transition correlate with phases of the Great Divergence and Great Convergence. ''Technological Forecasting and Social Change''. Volume 95, June 2015, Page 163]; see also [https://www.springer.com/us/book/9783319177793 ''Great Divergence and Great Convergence. A Global Perspective''].</ref> thus the present-day convergence should be regarded as a continuation of the [[Great Divergence]].
==Limitations==
The fact that a country is poor does not guarantee that catch-up growth will be achieved. [[Moses Abramovitz]] emphasised the need for 'Social Capabilities' to benefit from catch-up growth. These include an ability to absorb new technology, attract capital and participate in global markets. According to Abramovitz, these prerequisites must be in place in an economy before catch-up growth can occur, and explain why there is still divergence in the world today.
The theory also assumes that technology is freely traded and available to developing countries that are attempting to catch-up. Capital that is expensive or unavailable to these economies can also prevent catch-up growth from occurring, especially given that capital is scarce in these countries. This often traps countries in a low-efficiency cycle whereby the most efficient technology is too expensive to be acquired. The differences in productivity techniques is what separates the leading developed nations from the following developed nations, but by a margin narrow enough to give the following nations an opportunity to catch-up. This process of catch-up continues as long as the following nations have something to learn from the leading nations, and will only cease when the knowledge discrepancy between the leading and following nations becomes very small and eventually exhausted.
According to Professor [[Jeffrey Sachs]], convergence is not occurring everywhere because of the closed economic policy of some developing countries, which could be solved through [[free trade]] and openness. In a study of 111 countries between 1970 and 1989, Sachs and Andrew Warner concluded that the industrialized countries had a growth of 2.3%/year/capita, [[open economy]] developing countries 4.5% and [[closed economy]] developing countries only 2%.<ref>"Vapaakauppa on kriiseistä huolimatta kasvun eliksiiri", [[Jeffrey Sachs]], [[Helsingin Sanomat]] 1997-11-8 (the biggest newspaper in Finland)</ref>
[[Robert E. Lucas, Jr.|Robert Lucas]] stated the "[[Lucas paradox|Lucas Paradox]]" which is the observation that capital is not flowing from [[developed countries]] to [[developing countries]] despite the fact that developing countries have lower levels of capital per worker.<ref name="Lucas1990">{{citation | last1 = Lucas | first1 = Robert | author-link =Robert E. Lucas, Jr. | year=1990 |title= Why doesn't Capital Flow from Rich to Poor Countries? | journal = [[American Economic Review]] | volume = 80| pages = 92–96}}</ref> This statement, however, has received recently serious objections.<ref>[[Andrey Korotayev]], Julia Zinkina, Justislav Bogevolnov, and Artemy Malkov. [http://cliodynamics.ru/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=316&Itemid=1 Global Unconditional Convergence among Larger Economies after 1998?]. ''Journal of Globalization Studies'' 2/2 (2011): 25–62.</ref>
==Examples== There are many examples of countries which have converged with developed countries which validate the catch-up theory.<ref>[[Andrey Korotayev|Korotayev A.]], Zinkina J. [http://cliodynamics.ru/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=361&Itemid=1 On the structure of the present-day convergence. ''Campus-Wide Information Systems''. Vol. 31 No. 2/3, 2014, pp. 139-152]</ref> Based on case studies on Japan, Mexico and other countries, Nakaoka studied social capabilities for industrialization and clarified features of human and social attitudes in the catching-up process of Japan in the [[Meiji period]] (1868-1912).<ref>Nakaoka, T. (1987) On technological leaps of Japan as a developing country. Osaka City University Economic Review, 22, 1-25.</ref><ref>Nakaoka, T. (1994). The learning process and the market: the Japanese capital goods sector in the early twentieth century. LSE STICERD Research Paper No. JS271.</ref><ref>Nakaoka, T. (1996). Technology in Japan: From the Opening of Ports to the Start of the Postwar Economic Growth. Technological Development and Economic Systems: Japanese Experiences and Lessons: October 1–2, 1994, Tokyo, Japan.</ref><ref>Nakaoka, T. (Ed.) (1990) InternationalComparisonof Technological Formation-social capability of industrialization. Tokyo, Chikumashobo (Japanese).</ref><ref>Nakaoka, T. (1982) Science and technology in the history of modern Japan: imitation or endogenous creativity? in A. Abdel-Malek, G. Blue and M. Pecujlic (Eds.) Science and Technology in the Transformation of the World, The United Nations University, 1982. {{ISBN|92-808-0339-5}}</ref> In the 1960s and 1970s the [[East Asian Tigers]] rapidly converged with developed economies. These include [[Singapore]], [[Hong Kong]], [[South Korea]] and [[Taiwan]] - all of which are today considered developed economies. In the post-war period (1945–1960) examples include [[West Germany]], [[France]] and [[Japan]], which were able to quickly regain their prewar status by replacing capital that was lost during [[World War II]].
Some economists criticise the theory, stating that [[endogenous]] factors, such as government policy, are much more influential in economic growth than [[exogenous factor]]s. For example, [[Alexander Gerschenkron]] states that governments can substitute for missing prerequisites to trigger catch-up growth. A hypothesis by economic historians [[Kenneth Sokoloff]] and [[Stanley Engerman]] suggested that [[factor endowment]]s are a central determinant of [[structural inequality]] that impedes institutional development in some countries. Sokoloff and Engerman proposed that in the 19th century, countries such as Brazil and Cuba with rich factor endowments such as soil and climate are predisposed to a guarded franchise with limited institutional growth. Land that is suitable for sugar and coffee such as Cuba experienced economies of scale from the establishment of plantation that in turn created the small elite families with vested interest in guarded franchise. The exogenous suitability of land for wheat versus sugar determines the growth rate for many countries. Therefore, countries with land that is suitable for sugar converge with other countries that also have land that is suitable for growing sugar.
Sokoloff and Engerman explained this convergence in their article "History Lessons: Institutions, Factor Endowments, and Paths of Development in the New World." They explained that the United States and Canada started out as two of the poorest colonies in the New World but grew faster than other countries as a result of their soil qualities. They argued that the United States and Canada had land suitable for growing wheat which meant that they had small scale farming, since wheat does not benefit from economies of scale, and this led to a relatively equal distribution of wealth and political power enabling the population to vote for broad public education. This differentiated them from countries such as Cuba that had land suitable for growing sugar and coffee. Such countries did benefit from economies of scale and so had large plantation agriculture with slave labor, large income and class inequalities, and limited voting rights. This difference in political power led to little spending on the establishment of institutions such as public schools and slowed down their progress. As a result, countries with relative equality and access to public education grew faster and were able to converge on countries with inequality and limited education.<ref>Kenneth L. Sokoloff, Stanley L. Engerman. "History Lessons: Institutions, Factor Endowments, and Paths of Development in the New World". ''The Journal of Economic Perspectives'' Vol 14 No.3 (2000): pp. 217-232</ref>
==Types of Convergence==
* Absolute Convergence: Lower initial GDP will lead to a higher average growth rate. The implication of this is that poverty will ultimately disappear 'by itself'. It does not explain why some nations have had zero growth for many decades (e.g. in Sub-Saharan Africa)
* Conditional Convergence: A country's income per worker converges to a country-specific long-run level as determined by the structural characteristics of that country. The implication is that structural characteristics, and not initial national income, determine the long-run level of GDP per worker. Thus, foreign aid should focus on structure (infrastructure, education, financial system etc.) and there is no need for an income transfer from richer to poorer nations.
* Club Convergence: It is possible to observe different "clubs" or groups of countries with similar growth trajectories. Most importantly, several countries with low national income also have low growth rates. Thus, this is in contrast to the theory of conditional convergence, and would suggest that foreign aid should also include income transfers and that initial income does in fact matter for economic growth.

New Political Economy, 2006. * [https://www.jstor.org/stable/2122171 Moses Abramovitz, Catching Up, Forging Ahead and Falling Behind. Journal of Economic History, 1986.] * K. Sokoloff and S. Engerman, “Institutions, Factor Endowments, and Paths of Development in the New World,” Journal of Economic Perspectives, (Summer 2000), p. 217-32.

[[File:Douglas_C-53D_Dakota_LN-WND_Dakota_Norway_(7450550318).jpg|thumb|right|250px]] '''Dakota Norway''' is a Norwegian [[nonprofit foundation]], which operates and owns Norway’s only ''[[Douglas C-47 Skytrain]]'', based at [[Sandefjord Airport]] in [[Vestfold|Vestfold County]].<ref>https://www.nrk.no/vestfold/dakotaflyet-pa-torp-har-ny-motor-1.12193316</ref><ref>https://www.nrk.no/vestfold/dakota-far-1945-look-1.8132573</ref><ref>http://perspektiv.wideroe.no/utgivelser/04-15/bak-uniformen/</ref><ref>https://www.sb.no/stiftelsen-dakota-norway/kreftforeningen/torp/en-minnerik-dag-for-kreftsyke-barn/s/5-73-249337</ref> It is Norway’s only flying veteran passenger aircraft.<ref>https://www.aftenposten.no/norge/i/WO2eK/Gammel-dame-summer-videre</ref><ref>https://www.klikk.no/produkthjemmesider/vimenn/gamle-vinger-over-vestfold-3174860</ref> The aircraft was first in service for the [[U.S. Air Force]] in 1943, but was purchased by [[Finland]] in 1948 and utilized by [[Finnair]] until 1969. Thore Virik and Arne Karlsen of Sandefjord purchased the aircraft from the [[Finnish Air Force]] in 1985. It has done regular flights in Vestfold County since August 1986.<ref>http://dakotanorway.no/om-stiftelsen/</ref>
The DC 3 Dakota was Finnish President [[Urho Kekkonen]]'s private presidential plane during his time in office. Constructed in 1942, the vintage veteran airplane can be rented for domestic- or international flights during summer.<ref>https://www.visitnorway.com/listings/historical-flights-with-dakota-norway/3588/</ref>

{{Infobox song | name = Dance You Off | cover = Dance_You_Off_by_Benjamin_Ingrosso.jpg | alt = | type = single | artist = [[Benjamin Ingrosso]] | album = [[Identification (Benjamin Ingrosso album)|Identification]] | released = 2 March 2018 | format = [[Music download|Digital download]] | recorded = | studio = | venue = | genre = {{hlist|[[Ballad]], [[Eurodance]] |{{cite web|url=https://www.eurovision.de/news/ESC-2018-Benjamin-Ingrosso-startet-fuer-Schweden,schweden1156.html|title=ESC 2018: Benjamin Ingrosso startet für Schweden|first=|last=NDR|website=www.eurovision.de|accessdate=2 April 2018}}}} | length = | label = | writer = {{hlist|MAG|[[Louis Schoorl]]|K Nita|[[Benjamin Ingrosso]]}} | producer = | prev_title = [[One More Time (Benjamin Ingrosso song)|One More Time]] | prev_year = 2017 | next_title = [[Tror du att Han Bryr Sig]] | next_year = 2018 | misc = {{External music video|{{YouTube|MNrA69ID76U|"Dance You Off"}} }} {{Infobox song contest entry | embed = yes | song = {{flagicon|Sweden}} "Dance You Off" | image = | caption = | year = 2018 | country = Sweden | artist = [[Benjamin Ingrosso]] | language = English | languages = | composer = {{hlist|MAG|[[Louis Schoorl]]|K Nita|[[Benjamin Ingrosso]]}} | lyricist = {{hlist|MAG|[[Louis Schoorl]]|K Nita|[[Benjamin Ingrosso]]}} | conductor = | place = 7th | points = 274 | place_semi = 2nd | points_semi = 254 | prev = I Can't Go On | prev_year = 2017 | prev_link = I Can't Go On | next = | next_year = | next_link = }} }} "'''Dance You Off'''" is a 2018 song by Swedish singer [[Benjamin Ingrosso]].{{cite web|url=https://www.aftonbladet.se/nojesbladet/melodifestivalen/a/2183n4/benjamin-ingrosso-sjunger-om-sin-karlekskris-morkt|title=Benjamin Ingrosso sjunger om sin kärlekskris: "Mörkt"|work=Aftonbladet|accessdate=27 February 2018}} The song won [[Melodifestivalen 2018]], and made it to the final from the first semifinal. It was released in February 2018.{{cite web|url=https://www.svt.se/videoplayer-embed/nojs/1385145-007A|title=Benjamin Ingrosso – Dance You Off|website=www.svt.se|accessdate=27 February 2018}} The song won Melodifestivalen and represented Sweden in the [[Eurovision Song Contest 2018]] in [[Lisbon]], Portugal.{{cite web|url=http://wiwibloggs.com/2018/03/10/sweden-benjamin-ingrosso-wins-melodifestivalen-2018-dance-you-off/219401/|title=Sweden:Benjamin Ingrosso wins Melodifestivalen 2018 with "Dance You Off"- wiwibloggs|date=10 March 2018|publisher=wiwibloggs}} ==Melodifestivalen== Being Ingrosso's second participation in the Swedish Eurovision selection, "Dance You Off" participated in the first semi-final of the [[Melodifestivalen 2018|2018 Melodifestivalen]] which was held in [[Karlstad]]'s [[Löfbergs Arena]] on 3 February 2018. The song was performed last at the semi-final and it direct qualified to the final as it got the most points in the semi-final. On 10 March, during the final at the [[Friends Arena]] in [[Solna]], Ingrosso performed the song at the eleventh position of the running order. "Dance You Off" won the selection with 114 points from the international juries and 67 points from the public vote, receiving 181 points in total.{{cite web|url=https://eurovision.tv/story/benjamin-ingrosso-to-represent-sweden-in-eurovision-2018|title=Sweden's Benjamin Ingrosso to 'dance you off' in Lisbon!|date=10 March 2018|publisher=eurovision.tv}} ==Eurovision Song Contest== {{See also|Sweden in the Eurovision Song Contest 2018}} "Dance You Off" was performed on 10 May 2018 in the second semi-final of Eurovision Song Contest in [[Lisbon]], Portugal. The song made it to the Grand final, where it placed seventh with 274 points. It received the maximum 12 points from the juries of eight countries.{{cite web|url=https://www.expressen.se/noje/benjamin-ingrossos-lyxfest-i-natt-nu-ska-jag-fira/|title=Benjamin Ingrossos lyxfest i natt: ”Nu ska jag fira”|work=[[Expressen]]|date=13 May 2018|accessdate=14 May 2018|language=Swedish|last1=Thomsen|first1=Dante|last2=Svensson|first2=Ellinor|quote=Åtta 12-poängare från juryn – men bara 21 poäng av folket.|location=[[Lisbon]], [[Portugal]]}}{{cite web|url=https://www.expressen.se/noje/da-avgors-eurovision-song-contest/|title=Israel vinner allt – Ingrosso sänktes totalt av tittarna|work=[[Expressen]]|date=13 May 2018|accessdate=14 May 2018|language=Swedish|last=Nilsson|first=Anton|quote=Åtta länder gav tolvpoängare till Benjamin Ingrosso – Georgien, Lettland, Australien, Serbien, Cypern, Armenien, Tyskland och Slovenien.}} ==Track listing== {{Track listing | headline = Digital download{{cite web|url=https://itunes.apple.com/au/album/dance-you-off-single/1340825986|title=Dance You Off - Single by Benjamin Ingrosso|publisher=iTunes Australia|accessdate=12 May 2018}} | title1 = Dance You Off | length1 = 3:02 }} {{Track listing | headline = Digital download (LiTek remix){{cite web|url=https://itunes.apple.com/au/album/dance-you-off-litek-remix-single/1376962119|title=Dance You Off (LiTek remix)- Single by Benjamin Ingrosso|publisher=iTunes Australia|accessdate=12 May 2018}} | title1 = Dance You Off | length1 = 3:21 }} {{Track listing | headline = Digital download (Galavant remix){{cite web|url=https://itunes.apple.com/au/album/dance-you-off-galavant-remix-single/1378778850|title=Dance You Off (Galavant remix)- Single by Benjamin Ingrosso|publisher=iTunes Australia|accessdate=12 May 2018}} | title1 = Dance You Off | length1 = 3:47 }} ==Charts== {| class="wikitable sortable plainrowheaders" style="text-align:center" |- ! scope="col"| Chart (2018) ! scope="col"| Peak
position |- {{single chart|France|78|id=1742853|artist=Benjamin Ingrosso|song=Dance You Off|rowheader=true|accessdate=18 May 2018}} |- ! scope="row"| Greece Digital Singles ([[IFPI Greece]]){{cite web|url=http://www.ifpi.gr/digital_el.html|publisher=IFPI.gr|title=Official IFPI Charts-Digital Singles Chart|language=Greek|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180530205013/http://ifpi.gr/digital_iel.html|archivedate=30 May 2018}} | 65 |- ! scope="row"| Iceland ([[RÚV]]){{cite web|url=http://www.ruv.is/thaettir/vinsaeldalisti-rasar-2|publisher=[[RÚV]]|archive-url=http://www.freezepage.com/1527188284CDMWMURLCY|dead-url=yes|archive-date=24 May 2018|title=TOPPLISTINN 26. MAI 2018|accessdate=25 May 2018}} | 15 |- {{single chart|Poland|35|chartid=2752|year=2018|rowheader=true|accessdate=9 July 2018}} |- ! scope="row"| Spain ([[Productores de Música de España|PROMUSICAE]]){{cite web|url=http://www.promusicae.es/listas/semana/3730-canciones-semana-20-2018|title=Top 100 Canciones – Semana 20: del 11.05.2018 al 17.05.2018|publisher=[[Productores de Música de España]]|accessdate=23 May 2018|language=Spanish|format=PDF}} | 69 |- {{single chart|Sweden|2|artist=Benjamin Ingrosso|song=Dance You Off|rowheader=true|accessdate=17 March 2018}} |- {{single chart|Scotland|80|date=20180518|rowheader=true|accessdate=19 May 2018}} |- {{single chart|UKdownload|61|date=20180518|rowheader=true|accessdate=18 May 2018}} |} ==Certifications== {{Certification Table Top}} {{Certification Table Entry|type=single|region=Sweden|artist=Benjamin Ingrosso|title=Dance You Off|award=Platinum|certyear=2018|relyear=2018|recent=false|certref={{cite web|url=http://www.sverigetopplistan.se|title=Benjamin - Dance You Off|accessdate=22 May 2018|publisher=Sverigetopplistan}}}} {{Certification Table Bottom|format=3col}} ==References== {{reflist}} {{Benjamin Ingrosso}} {{Sweden in the Eurovision Song Contest}} {{Eurovision Song Contest 2018 |state=collapsed}} [[Category:2018 singles]] [[Category:Songs about dancing]] [[Category:English-language Swedish songs]] [[Category:Melodifestivalen songs of 2018]] [[Category:Eurovision songs of Sweden]] [[Category:Eurovision songs of 2018]] [[Category:Swedish pop songs]] {{Sweden-stub}} {{2010s-single-stub}}

{{Infobox play | name = Each In His Own Way | writer = [[Luigi Pirandello]] | characters = ''In the play:''
Delia Morello
Michele Rocca
Donna Livia Pelegari
Doro Pelegari, ''her son''
Diego Cenci, ''his friend''
Francesco Savio

''In the audience:''
Amelia Moreno
Baron Nuti
Theatre personnel | setting = a [[theatre]] in [[Rome]]
characters' houses in Rome | premiere = {{Start date|1924|05|22}} | place = [[Milan]] | orig_lang = [[Italian language|Italian]] | series = ''[[Six Characters in Search of an Author]]'', ''[[Tonight We Improvise]]'' | genre = [[tragicomedy]] }} '''''Each In His Own Way''''' ({{lang-it|Ciascuno a suo modo}} {{IPA-it|tʃaˈskuːno a ˈsuːo ˈmɔːdo|}}) is a 1924 play by [[Luigi Pirandello]]. Like his more famous ''[[Six Characters in Search of an Author]]'', it forms part of his "trilogy of the [[Metatheatre|theatre in the theatre]]." ''Each In His Own Way'' concerns the production of a play based on "real" goings-on: the scandal of the artist Giorgio Salvi's suicide on the eve of his marriage, committed when he discovered that his fiancée, the actress Delia Morello, had begun a short-lived affair with Salvi's brother-in-law Michele Rocca, is ostensibly based on events concerning the sculptor La Vela, the actress Amelia Moreno, and Baron Nuti. The people in question have come separately to see the "play" to determine if it is really based on the real events. The "play" begins ''[[in medias res]]'', with the characters discussing Delia. Two characters, Doro Palegari and Francesco Savio, debate her rationale: was it a well-intentioned move to break off a marriage that would have been a mistake, or was it spite against Salvi? By the end of Act I, Moreno and Nuti have independently confirmed that the play is based on their story, and Moreno wishes to stop it from going on. However, it continues, and Act II shows Rocca's arrival to tell Delia that he has realized their mutual hatred is concealed love; she rejects him and they fight, but then she realizes he is right, and they embrace. In the auditorium, Moreno and Nuti, still furious, catch sight of each other and likewise embrace. Act III is "canceled." ==References== *[http://www.pirandelloweb.com/teatro/1924_ciascuno_a_suo_modo/ciascuno_a_suo_modo.htm Text of the play (Italian)] {{Luigi Pirandello}} [[Category:1924 plays]] [[Category:Plays by Luigi Pirandello]] [[Category:Italian plays]] [[Category:Tragicomedy plays]] [[Category:Self-reflexive plays]] [[Category:Works set in theatres and opera houses]] {{1920s-play-stub}} {{Italy-stub}}

[[Mirontsy]], [[Comoros]]| capacity = 1,000| chairman = | manager = | league = [[Comoros Premier League]]| season = | position = | }} '''Etoile d'Or Mirontsy FC''' is a [[Comoros|Comorian]] [[football (soccer)|football]] club located in [[Mirontsy]], [[Comoros]]. It currently plays in the [[Comoros Premier League]]. In 2008 the team has won the [[Comoros Premier League]]. ==Honours== *'''[[Comoros Premier League]]: 1''' ::2008 ==Stadium== Currently the team plays at the 1000 capacity [[Stade de Mirontsy]].http://www.worldstadiums.com/africa/countries/comoros.shtml ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== *[https://int.soccerway.com/teams/comoros/etoile-dor-mirontsy/13050/ Team profile] – ''soccerway.com'' [[Category:Football clubs in the Comoros]] {{Comoros-sport-stub}} {{Africa-footyclub-stub}}

[[File:Nigel_Farage_MEP_1,_Strasbourg_-_Diliff_(cropped).jpg|thumb|right|Nigel Farage]] '''Faragism''' is an [[ideology]] and practice associated with the followers and supporters of [[Nigel Farage]], leader of the [[UK Independence Party]] from 2006 to 2009 and then again from 2010 to 2016. Faragism is a [[Conservatism|conservative]], [[Populism|populist]] and strongly [[Euroscepticism|Eurosceptic]] ideology. It is the leading ideology among members of [[UK Independence Party|UKIP]], but it is also popular with many in the [[Conservative Party (UK)|Conservative Party]].
==2016 UKIP leadership election== One of the first declared Faragists was [[Raheem Kassam]], when he announced his intention to run for the leadership of UKIP in the [[UK Independence Party leadership election, November 2016|November 2016 election]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-politics-37799679 |title='Farage-ist' Raheem Kassam launches UKIP leadership bid |publisher=BBC News |date=2016-10-28 |accessdate=2017-07-06}}</ref> Kassam defined it as "a belief in your country, a belief in your culture, a belief in the people of this great nation.”<ref>{{cite web|author=Peter Walker |url=https://www.theguardian.com/politics/2016/oct/28/ukip-leadership-candidate-raheem-kassam-donald-trump-niqab-referendum |title=leadership candidate defends Trump and calls for niqab referendum |publisher=The Guardian |date=2016-10-28 |accessdate=2017-07-06}}</ref>
Another declared Faragist candidate in November 2016 was [[John Rees-Evans]]. Sam Gould, the Chairman of UKIP Caerphilly confirmed this, commenting “Yes – policy-wise he is similar to Raheem. John is a gentlemen and has done so much for UKIP, helping them produce party political broadcasts and has raised a lot of money for the party, too.”<ref>{{cite web|last=Smith |first=Jack |url=http://newmediacentral.net/ukip-leadership-latest-john-rees-evans-walks-out-of-hustings-event/ |title=UKIP leadership latest – John Rees-Evans walks out of hustings event |publisher=New Media Central |date=2016-11-03 |accessdate=2017-07-06}}</ref> [[Paul Nuttall]], who won the 2016 leadership contest having pitched himself as the unity candidate, appointed [[Suzanne Evans]] as co-deputy chairwoman of the party and [[Patrick O'Flynn]] as his principal political adviser. Both individuals have been seen as opponents of Farage within the party.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Fisher|first1=Lucy|title=Farage's old foe gets seat at top table|url=http://www.thetimes.co.uk/edition/news/farage-s-old-foe-gets-seat-at-top-table-fb86kl9jz|work=The Times|subscription=y|date=30 November 2016}}</ref>
==References==

{{Infobox building | name = Harsdorff House | native_name = Harsdorffs Hus | image = Harsdorffs Hus (Kongens Nytorv).JPG | image_alt = | caption = The Harsdorff House viewed from [[Kongens Nytorv]] | former_names = | alternate_names = | map_type = | map_alt = | map_caption = | building_type = | architectural_style = [[Neoclassical architecture|Neoclassicism]] | structural_system = | cost = | location = [[Copenhagen]] | client = | owner = [[Karberghus]] | current_tenants = | landlord = | location_country = [[Denmark]] | coordinates = {{coord|55|40|47.92|N|12|35|12.56|E|type:landmark_region:DK|display=inline,title}} | altitude = | start_date = 1779 | completion_date = 1780 | inauguration_date = | demolition_date = | height = | diameter = | other_dimensions = | floor_count = | floor_area = | main_contractor = | architect = [[Caspar Frederik Harsdorff]] | structural_engineer = | services_engineer = | civil_engineer = | other_designers = | quantity_surveyor = | awards = | url = | references = }}
The '''Harsdorff House''' is a historic property located on [[Kongens Nytorv]] in central [[Copenhagen]], [[Denmark]]. It was built by [[Caspar Frederik Harsdorff]] in 1780 and was in the same time to serve as inspiration for the many uneducated master builders of the time. The [[Minister of Foreign Affairs (Denmark)|Ministry of Foreign Affairs]] was based in the building from 1864 to 1823.
==History== [[File:Charlottenborg 1749 (2).png|thumb|200px|left|The small buildings located next to Charlottenborg seen on a drawing from the middle of the 18th century]] [[Caspar Frederik Harsdorff]] became professor of perspective at the [[Royal Danish Academy of Fine Arts]] in 1766. In 1770 he succeeded [[Nicolas-Henri Jardin]] as royal building master and the following year he took over his residence in the south wing of [[Charlottenborg Palace]].The Royal Academy's secretary, C. E. Biehl, had a residence next to the palace. His daughter, [[Charlotte Dorothea Biehl]], spend some of her childhood in the building. After Biehl's death the worn-out building was designated for demolition and Harsdorff was consulted on the matter. He proposed that the site was given to him and he would then build a house which could serve as inspiration for the builders of the increasing number of bourgeois houses in the city. Architects who had studied at the Academy were in general only used by the state and members of the aristocracy. The king accepted the offer.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.kobenhavnshistorie.dk/bog/kko/h/kko_h-3.html|title=Harsdorffs Hus, Kongens Nytorv 3-5|language=Danish|website=Selskabet for Københavns Historie|accessdate=22 March 2016}}</ref> Construction began in 1779 and was completed in 1780.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.multimediakontoret.dk/programmer/arkitektur/klasicm/H1_004.htm#hars|title=Borgerhuset|language=Danish|website=multimediakontoret.dk|accessdate=22 March 2016}}</ref> The building was never actually used by Harsdorff personally. It was instead used as the city home of C. F. E. Rantzau .
[[File:Jacques Eugene Pierre Vincent (1806-1849).jpg|thumb|160px|Jacques Eugene Pierre Vincent]] A Frenchman, Eugen Vincent, who had previously served as cook for Prince Ferdinand, opened Restairant Vincent in the building in the first half of the 19th century. The restaurant was later operated by his widow Eva Severine Vincent (née Rasmussen) and son Alexander Vincent under the name Madame Vincent. It was visited y [[Jules Verne]] during his visit to Copenhagen in 1861.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.jules-verne.dk/verneikoebenhavn1861.html|title=Jules Verne i København i billeder|language=Danish|website=jules-verne.dk|accessdate=14 March 2017}}</ref>
The merchant and politician [[Alfred Hage (1803–1872)|Alfred Hage]] lived in the building from 1862 and until his death in 1872.
[[File:Harsdorffs Hus 1866.jpg|thumb|200px|left|The Harsdorff House photographed in 1866]] The [[Minister of Foreign Affairs (Denmark)|Ministry of Foreign Affairs]] was based in the building from 1864 until 1923. It was from then on based partly at [[Christiansborg Palace]] and the [[Yellow Mansion, Copenhagen|Yellow Mansion]] in [[Amaliegade]] until its new building at [[Asiatisk Plads]] was completed in 1983.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://indenforvoldene.dk/kongens%20nytorv%203-5.html|title=Kongens Nytorv 3-5|language=Danish|website=indenforvoldene.dk|accessdate=22 March 2016}}</ref> The building was restored by Fogh & Følner in 1999.<ref name=arkark>{{cite web|url=http://www.arkark.dk/building.aspx?buildingid=1896|title=Harsdorffs Palæ, København|language=Danish|website=aarkark.dk|accessdate=22 March 2016}}</ref>
Court photographyer Jens Petersen, 1829-1905 operated a photographic studio in the building from 1865 to 1875.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.fotohistorie.com/petersen-jens-kbh.html|title=Harsdorffs Palæ, København|language=Danish|website=fotohistorie.com|accessdate=10 September 2018}}</ref>
==Architecture== As Jardin's successor,c. f. Harsdorff favoured French classicism inspired by ancient Greece and Rome.<ref name=arkark/>
The odd-shaped corner site inspired Harsdorff to build a property with three different model facades. The more monumental, central section is decorated with Ionic order pilasters and crowned by a triangular pediment with relief decoration.
The house came to serve as inspiration for hundreds of houses in the rebuilding of Copenhagen during the years after the [[Copenhagen Fire of 1795|Great Fire of 1795]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.guldalder.dk/Harsdorffs_Hus.html|title=1. Harsdorffs Hus|language=Danish|website=Golden Days|accessdate=22 March 2016}}</ref>
==Today== The building is owned by [[Karberghus]]. The tenants include the IT consultency Nine (No. 3-5, 1st floor) and Russel Reynolds Associates (No. 3, 2md floor)
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== * [http://kunstbib.dk/samlinger/arkitekturtegninger/vaerker/000030766/1 Architectural renderings] from the [[Danish National Art Library]] * [http://www.fotohistorie.com/atelierer-indre-by.html Source] * [http://www.officeclub.dk/en/blog/read/549698150/three-worlds-two-meetings-one-intermediary Source]
[[Category:Gammelholm]] [[Category:Houses in Copenhagen]] [[Category:Caspar Frederik Harsdorff buildings]] [[Category:Houses completed in 1780]]
{{Denmark-stub}}
[[da:Harsdorffs Hus]]

The '''Landen Group''' is a [[lithostratigraphy|lithostratigraphic]] unit (a "[[group (stratigraphy)|group]]" of [[stratum|rock strata]]) in the [[Belgium|Belgian]] [[Subsurface (geology)|subsurface]]. The group consists of two [[formation (stratigraphy)|formations]] of [[Thanetian]] (late [[Paleocene]]) to [[Ypresian]] (early [[Eocene]]) age. The Landen Group is named after the town of [[Landen]] in [[Flemish Brabant]].
==Subdivision== The Landen Group is subdivided into two formations: * The [[Hannut Formation]], an alternation of [[marine (ocean)|marine]] [[clay]]s, [[sand]]s and [[limestone]]s; * The [[Tienen Formation]], a [[lagoon]]al-[[continent]]al alternation of clay, sand and [[lignite]]. This formation is known for its fossils.
Both formations can be found in the subsurface of all northern Belgium. They [[outcrop|crop out]] in the [[Hainaut (province)|province of Hainaut]].
==Stratigraphy== The Landen Group is stratigraphically on top of the [[Bertaimont Formation]] or [[Heers Formation]] (marine [[marl]]s, sands and clays of [[Selandian]] to Thanetian age). In the Belgian lithostratigraphy, the Landen Group is overlain by the [[Ieper Group]], marine clays and sands of Ypresian age.
The Landen Group shares its name with the [[Landen Formation]] in the lithostratigraphy of the [[Netherlands]]. However, this Dutch formation contains not only the equivalents of the Belgian Landen Group but also strata that [[correlation|correlate]] with the Belgian [[Opglabbeek Formation]] and Heers Formation.
==References== *{{aut|Laga, P.; Louwye, S. & Geets, S.}} (eds.); 2001: ''Paleogene and Neogene lithostratigraphic units (Belgium)'', Geologica Belgica 4(1-2), p. 135-152
[[Category:Lithostratigraphy of Belgium]] [[Category:Eocene]] [[Category:Paleocene]] [[Category:Paleogene Europe]]

revision.text:
The '''Luxembourg Mathematical Society''' ('''SML''', '''Société mathématique du Luxembourg''') was founded in January 1989 on the initiative of Professor Jean-Paul Pier.
Its mission is the promotion of Pure and Applied Mathematics. The scope of action of the SML includes *the organization of conferences, workshops, seminars, round table discussions etc. *the edition of books, mathematical journals, newsletters etc. *the representation of Mathematics and the mathematics profession in Luxembourg inside and outside the Grand-Duchy of [[Luxembourg]]
The SML is a member of the [[European Mathematical Society]] (EMS). It has reciprocity agreements with the [[American Mathematical Society]] and the Royal Spanish Mathematical Society.
== External links == *[http://math.uni.lu/sml Homepage of the Luxembourg Mathematical Society]
{{The European Mathematical Society}}
[[Category:Mathematical societies]] [[Category:Organizations established in 1989]]
{{Luxembourg-stub}}
